Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Evaluating Political Competition Between Chacoan- Style Great Houses in the Southern Cibola Region, West-Central New Mexico

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Under the direction of Dr. Andrew Duff, and with support from the National Science Foundation, Kristin Safi's doctoral research at Washington State University will examine the degree to which localized political competition organized migrants into cooperative multi-ethnic settlements in west-central New Mexico, a unique cultural setting at the interface of two ancestral cultural traditions, the Pueblo and Mogollon. This research focuses on the A.D. 1050-1150 period, when migrants from both ancestral traditions formed multi-ethnic communities in this area centered around Chacoan-style great houses. These great houses represent scaled-down emulations of the monumental architecture found at Chaco Canyon, New Mexico. Chaco Canyon and the smaller great houses found throughout the Four Corners area has been argued to be a socially and/or politically integrated system of unparalleled scale in the ancient American Southwest. However, little research has investigated how great houses articulated with Chaco Canyon or the role great houses played within their local communities. This research aims to do so by evaluating how political competition between great house communities on the margins of the "Chacoan regional system" mitigated the social stresses caused by rapid population increase by groups from distinct ethnic traditions.

Research on migrant integration and community organization will better frame studies of identity expression within multi-ethnic communities and will further knowledge of the interplay between group affiliation and cooperation within multi-ethnic groups, questions relevant to studying migrant integration and community identity in contemporary heterogeneous populations worldwide.

This study focuses on the Largo Gap great house and its associated community. The study aims to: (1) characterize the construction and chronology of use at the Largo Gap great house; (2) characterize the Largo Gap support community, and the role of the great house within this community; (3) compare the settlement pattern around, and use of the Largo Gap great house to its two nearest neighbors, Cox Ranch Pueblo and Cerro Pomo; and (4) to explore the articulation between great houses in this region with contemporaneous great house communities across the Four Corners, which will help clarify the nature of the "Chacoan regional system." Systematic survey of lands surrounding Largo Gap and limited testing of the Largo Gap great house and associated community sites will provide the data needed to address these questions. These data, when combined with that collected by Duff at the Cox Ranch and Cerro Pomo great house communities, will permit Safi to evaluate models of political competition, multi-ethnic community integration, and great house function at local and regional scales.

This research promotes a wider appreciation for archaeological science and the preservation our national heritage. It also advances increased participation of women in science by training women at all educational levels to conduct archaeological research in the field and laboratory. This project promotes engagement between academia and descendent communities through consultation and research presentations, and engages local residents through community outreach to promote increased understanding of Native American history, the conservation of heritage resources, and to foster relationships between researchers, the descendants of these ancient communities, and the region's current residents.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the eleventh and twelfth centuries, social interaction in the American Southwest expanded to an unprecedented scale. Monumental buildings known as “great houses” were constructed within Chaco Canyon, New Mexico, which research suggests were used to host massive, periodic social/ritual events that were attend by individuals from all over the northern Southwest. Over 200 large buildings with similar architecture to those within Chaco were constructed across the Four Corners. These smaller great houses are considered to represent participation in a large social interaction system centered in Chaco by contemporaneous communities. Chaco’s modern prominence as a focus of Southwestern research and as a tourist attraction stems not only from the massive architectural remains, but also the “mysteries” surrounding the canyon’s occupants, social system, amount of social stratification, and way of life. Chief among these mysteries is why such large buildings, and possibly how such large populations, arose in what is now an ecologically barren canyon. Some have suggested a limitation on local resources provided the impetus for a regional system where great houses were constructed across the Southwest to transport economic goods into the canyon. An alternative regional model is based around the formation of a new ideology that established new rituals and beliefs enacted in great house settings. Both models rely on the use of iconic material items and architecture to link canyon and non-canyon populations. This project investigates the use of culturally iconic material items and architecture to signal community participation in an inferred regional social system and to identify what social, economic, or ritual factors linked communities across the northern Southwest during this time period.

 

The data collected through this project speak to questions of ethnic identity, multi-ethnic community formation, regional systems, and social networks viewed through resource exchange. Fieldwork focused on intensive excavation and settlement mapping in and around the Largo Gap great house in the southern Cibola sub-region of New Mexico, to generate samples comparable to two local, previously studied great house communities. The results indicate that the three great house communities, located on the southern periphery of the Chaco regional system, incorporated aspects of the Chaco architectural vernacular and mimicked some of the ritual and communal activities observed within Chaco Canyon on a smaller scale. Despite these similarities, southern Cibola great houses appear to be emulative constructions, rather directed construction by individuals within Chaco. In other words, participation in the regional system appears to have been voluntary, rather than economically extractive. Instead of strict adherence to Chacoan architectural styles, each of these communities incorporated elements from both the Mogollon and Pueblo cultural traditions, perhaps in an effort to better integrate constituent members of each ethnic identity during communal activities. These results are applicable to studying the formation of modern multi-ethnic communities in an increasingly globalized society, and the negotiation and display of person ethnic identity within such group settings. Further, the generated data demonstrate that great houses may have been constructed through competitive leadership/costly signaling displays as a means to gain access to a larger social network, possibly through ritual leadership centered in great houses.
